title: From fact-checking to friction-checking
description: For years, journalism has treated misinformation as a truth problem. A false story pops up, journalists or fact-checkers correct it, and the record is corrected. But today’s most damaging falsehoods do not spread because people believe them. They spread because they express anger, signal identity, build a sense of belonging, provoke humor, or even channel...
